Title: Travel Medicine
Overview:
Travel medicine focuses on prevention and management of health problems of international travelers. Globalization facilitates the spread of disease and increases the number of travelers who will be exposed to a different health environment. Major content areas of travel medicine include the global epidemiology of health risks to the traveler, vaccinology, malaria prevention, and pre-travel counseling designed to maintain the health of our beneficiary population. 


- From the **2013 Accreditation Handbook - AAAHC**, chapter 15, sub-chapter II — "Travel Medicine"
  > This subchapter applies only to organizations that provide travel medicine services.
  >
  > Organizations providing travel medicine services will ensure that these services are appropriate to the needs of the patient and are adequately supported by the organization’s clinical capabilities.
  >
  > 1. Travel medicine services are provided by personnel who have appropriate training, skills, and resource materials to provide quality services.
  > 2. Travel medicine programs include:
  >    - Appropriate medical oversight.
  >    - Clearly defined standing orders and protocols, including management of adverse reactions to immunizations.
  >    - Access to current Centers for Disease Control (CDC) and U.S. Department of State travel recommendations.
  >    - Appropriate storage and management of vaccines.
  > 3. Travel medicine services include:
  >    - Comprehensive travel destination-specific risk assessment.
  >    - Appropriate preventive medicine interventions.
  >    - Education in risk and risk reduction.
  > 4. Entries in a patient’s clinical record include:
  >    - Travel destination and current health status.
  >    - Immunization and vaccine name(s), dosage form, dosage administered, lot number, and quantity.
  >    - Prescription medications given, quantity and date, dosage, and directions for use.
  >    - Preventive health education.

Title: Epidemiology & Disease Surveillance
Overview: Air Force Disease Surveillance and Epidemiology programs are community health programs.  Public Health activities monitor disease and injury incidence to identify departure from background, or not "normal," rates.  When outbreaks of disease or clusters of injury are identified, public health functions to investigate these occurrences, identify risk factors, and implement effective interventions.  Surveillance and epidemiology also function to inform, evaluate and validate outcomes of public health policy.

Title: Occupational Hedsalthjo
Tags: health, oeh, health, , dead, See ya, huh
Overview:
IAW AFI 48-145, Occupational and Environmental Health Program, the purpose of the AF OEH Program is to protect health while enhancing combat and operational capabilities. The program is designed to mitigate OEH-related health risks through the optimum application of Aerospace Medicine capabilities. It seeks to identify, assess and eliminate or control health hazards associated with day-to-day operations across the full life-cycle of acquisition, sustainment and support for weapons systems, munitions and other materiel systems.

The *"Quality and Administration"* of OEH Medical Examinations and follow-up, is a Public Health function. Key duties include:

- Serves as member of the OEHWG, providing consultation on recommended OEH MSEs, OEH training requirements, risk communication, and OEH surveillance

- Manages the Occupational and Environmental Health Illness Program

- Manages the Installation Fetal Protection Program

- In conjunction with BE, acts as a consultant to workplace supervisors for OEH training. In coordination with BE, reviews and makes available training materials to workplace supervisors. PH will proactively offer training assistance (materials, consultation) to non-MTF workplaces with blood-borne pathogen hazards

- Provides administrative oversight of MSE program as directed by the IOEMC

- Acts as MTF or ARC medical unit liaison to local/community health department 

- When supporting an LSMTF or MAS with no PH officer assigned, oversees the OEH epidemiology and FHM aspects of the OEH Program at the GSUs or MUNSS sites. The level of involvement may range from simple oversight to performing the functions based on the technical expertise of the LSMTF or MAS personnel
Policy:
- AFI 10-203, *Duty Limiting Conditions*
	- This AFI establishes procedures for the documentation and administrative management of Airmen with injuries or illnesses that may impact their ability to perform their military duties. These procedures have been developed to ensure maximum utilization and readiness of personnel, while preserving their health and minimizing risk of further injury or illness. PH will review Aeromedical Services Information Management System (ASIMS) for all AF personnel arriving on the installation on PCS orders to ensure the member doesn’t have any medical readiness issues (immunization, dental, PHA, DLC, etc.). 

- AFI 44-102, *Medical Care Management*
	- This AFI discusses the role of Bioenvironmental Engineering (BE), PH, Flight Medicine (FOM) and Base Safety in assisting MTF providers through the Occupational and Environment Health Working Group (OEHWG) and how to evaluate, quantify risk, and manage work related injury and illness. Also, PH should have an effective prevention of work related illnesses and injuries begins with all medical providers developing a working knowledge of the major occupational activities taking place at their assigned installation. 
- AFI 48-101, *Aerospace Medicine Enterprise*
	- This AFI outlines that the AF Occupational and Environmental Health (OEH) Program is to protect military and civilian employee health while enhancing combat and operational capabilities. The key team aerospace players are BE, FOM, and PH, these members are responsible for desired effects, indicators, and reporting to OEHWG, AMC, and Installation Environmental, Safety and Occupational Health (ESOH) Council. 

- AFI 48-123, *Medical Examinations and Standards*
- AFI 48-145, *Occupational Health Program*
	- This AFI discusses that the AF OEH Program is to protect health while enhancing combat and operational capabilities. The program is designed to mitigate OEH-related health risks through the optimum application of Aerospace Medicine capabilities. It seeks to identify, assess and eliminate or control health hazards associated with day-to-day operations across the full lifecycle of acquisition, sustainment and support for weapons systems, munitions and other materiel systems. PH serves as a member of the OEHWG, providing consultation on recommended OEH Medical Surveillance Exams (MSE), OEH training requirements, risk communication, and OEH surveillance. 
- AFI 90-821, *Hazard Communication*
	- This AFI outlines that hazardous chemicals are found in virtually every AF operation, including aircraft and missile maintenance, civil engineering, transportation, supply, medical, and support functions. This AFI is intended to minimize the incidence of chemically induced occupational  and environmental health-related illnesses and injuries by establishing guidance for training employees on the health and physical hazards associated with and proper preventive measures to be taken when using or handling hazardous chemicals in work areas. Also, it provides the requirements for an effective AF Hazard Communication (HAZCOM) program for those work areas that have workers who handle or use hazardous chemicals. PH will review HAZCOM training plans for technical accuracy and completeness prior to implementation by the work area supervisor. 

- AFI 91-202, *The US Air Force Mishap Prevention Program*
	- This AFI establishes ways to minimize loss of AF resources and protect AF personnel from death, injuries or occupational illnesses by managing risks on-and off-duty. PH will communicate occupational health education requirements and available resources to supervisors; serve as the initial point of contact for occupational medical monitoring and will report cases of occupational illness to the installation ground safety office through AF Safety Automated System (AFSAS). Also, PH provides a representative to actively participate in ESOH Council to provide consultation on epidemiology, occupational illnesses, and other occupational health program areas. 

- AFI 91-204, *Safety Investigations and Reports*
	- This AFI provides guidance on investigating and reporting all USAF mishaps. PH is to ensure all occupational and environmental illnesses are investigated in a timely manner and documented in AFSAS. PH will report, monitor, and track occupational illness investigations until completion via the AFSAS Occupational Illness Module. After the provider makes the final determination on the illness report and prior to closing an investigation, PH will review each illness record to ensure internal (within individual report) and external (compared with other similar illness reports) consistency and that quality data has been captured and documented. PH will forward occupational illness information to the Occupational Safety and Health Administration (OSHA) 300 log via AFSAS (illness reports which are closed as occupationally-related illnesses are automatically included on the OSHA 300 log). 

- AFMAN 48-125, *Personnel Ionizing Radiation Dosimetry*
- AFOSHSTD 48-9, *Electro-Magnetic Frequency (EMF) Radiation Occupational Health Program*
- AFOSHSTD 48-20, *Occupational Noise and Hearing Conservation Program*
- AFI 48-137, *Respiratory Protection Program*
	- This AFI prescribes the requirements for a unit to have an effective respiratory protection program. PH must ensure the correct occupational health examinations are identified for all respirator wearers based on BE workplace assessment. Also, PH or Occupational Medicine Service (OMS) must ensure respirator medical questionnaires are administered to individuals placed on the respiratory protection program. 

- AFPD 48-1, *Aerospace Medicine Enterprise*
	- This instruction identifies the OEH Program as one of four key mission areas within the Aerospace Medicine Enterprise. The purpose of the OEH Program is to protect military and civilian employee health while enhancing combat and operational capabilities. 



Other DoD Issuances:

- DoDI 6055.05, *Occupational and Environmental Health, 11 Nov 2008*
	- This instruction expands risk management procedures to anticipate, recognize, evaluate, and control health hazards associated with occupational and environmental exposures to chemical, physical, and biological hazards in DoD workplaces to include military operations and deployments. 

- DoD 6055.05-M, *Occupational Medical Examinations and Surveillance Manual, IC1, 16 Sep 2008*
- DoDI 6055.5, *Industrial Hygiene and Occupational Health, IC1, 6 May 1996*
- 29 CFR 1910.95 Section 8, *Occupational Noise Exposure, Follow-up Procedures, 1 Jul 2005*

Title: VAERS
Overview:
The statute 42 USC 300aa-1 to 300aa-34 (*The National Childhood Vaccine Injury Act of 1986*), requires that the following events be reported to VAERS, a public health activity administered by the FDA and CDC:

- Any event listed in the NVIC program’s vaccine injury table (at http://www.hrsa.gov/vaccinecompensation/table.htm) occurring within the time period specified.
- Any contraindicating event listed in a vaccine’s package insert (product labeling).

Title: ESSENCE
Overview: ESSENCE guidance and resources
Policy:
**Department of Defense, Health Affairs guidance:**

"In accordance with HA Policy 07-001, use of ESSENCE must be a part of everyday medical surveillance activities at all levels of the MHS. As with the previous versions of ESSENCE, I (William Winkenwerder, Jr) expect each Service to mandate the use of ESSENCE at all installations where there are qualified public health or preventive medicine professionals. "

**Air Force specific guidance:**

"IAW, AFI 48-105, 1.10.6.1 , Public Health (active components) will "conduct community or location-specific public health surveillance, which includes chemical, biological, radiological, and nuclear (CBRN) terrorism and syndromic surveillance". 

**Command Responsibilities, c. MTF Commanders or OICs shall:** 

On DoD installations in the United States, ensure two trained ESSENCE users (one ofwhom may be the PHEO) are actively monitoring ESSENCE, which is the syndromic surveillance tool for the Department of Defense. For the NGB, ESSENCE shall be monitored centrally with applicable information pushed out to ARNG and ANG units as needed.

Title: Medical Employee Health
Overview: Tracking and mitigating hospital staff health concerns.
Policy:
- AFI 44-108, *Infection Prevention and Control Program*
	- This AFI describes procedures for preventing and controlling healthcare-associated infections (HAIs) in patients, visitors, volunteers, and staff (military, civilian, and contract personnel) within any healthcare setting such as MTFs. PH provides health status reports to the Infection Prevention and Control Function (ICF), disease monitoring in the Medical Employee Health Program (MEHP) and reports medical employee health screening status of MTF employees at least annually. 

- AFI 48-137, *Respiratory Protection Program*
	- This AFI prescribes the requirements for an effective respiratory protection program. PH ensures those occupational activities that may expose or potentially expose medical personnel to airborne infectious diseases are recommended to BE. Also, PH recommends patient care areas that may require respiratory protection based on potential exposures to infectious diseases. Medical providers conduct a medical evaluation of individuals identified to wear a respirator; and determine fitness to use the respiratory protection specified in the individual’s workplace-specific plan and/or medical evaluation questionnaire. 

Go to: [E-Pubs](http://www.e-publishing.af.mil/) website


- [MMWR Vol. 60/No. RR-7](http://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/pdf/rr/rr6007.pdf), *Immunization of Health-Care Personnel: Recommendations of the Advisory Committee on Immunization Practices (ACIP), 27 Nov 2011*
	- This CDC publication summarizes all current ACIP recommendations for vaccination of healthcare personnel in the United States and can assist hospital administrators, infection control practitioners, employee health physicians, and healthcare workers in optimizing infection prevention and control programs. The recommendations for vaccinating healthcare personnel are presented by disease in two categories: Those diseases for which vaccination or documentation of immunity is recommended because of risks to HCP in work settings for acquiring disease or transmitting to patients and those for which vaccination might be indicated in certain circumstances.

>Q: Who is certified to conduct local Food Vulnerability Assessments?
A: *Must be a PHO/NCOIC (7-lvl or 9-lvl) or Certified 5-lvl or IDMT*

>Q: How can I get my installation scheduled for an HHQ FVA?
A: *All HHQ FVAs are scheduled based on the JSIVA/AFVAT FY schedule.  This schedule is typically finalized and released to MAJCOMs Jul/Aug prior to FY.*

>Q: How many facilities do I need to assess during the local FVA?
A: *An Annual FVA will include 100% of the establishments and assets that provide food for consumption to a base population.* 

>Q: Where should I send the local FVA final report to?
A: *Prepare report and deliver findings through official forum (e.g. ATWG/FPWG/PSWG) and forward FVA Report to USAFSAM/PHR via SIPRNET*

Title: Food Protection
Overview:
Air Force Food Protection programs (Defense and Safety) focus on ensuring safe food to the Air Force community as well as addressing security concerns. AF Public Health is the Regulatory Authority for food facillity evaluations within AF installations.

When foodborne outbreaks do occur, Public Health responds to determine the cause and source of illness. Usually, outbreaks are naturally occurring, but with terrorist threats, intentional contamination must be considered.

This section provides specific information on how Public Health can effectively prevent and respond to foodborne outbreaks and emphasizes Food Protection related policy, resources, and tools.

Title: Markdown Help
Overview: > The cheatsheet below is provided by [markdown-here](https://github.com/adam-p/markdown-here/wiki/Markdown-Cheatsheet) ## Headers # H1 ## H2 ### H3 #### H4 ##### H5 ###### H6 Alternatively, for H1 and H2, an underline-ish style: Alt-H1 ====== Alt-H2 ------ ## Emphasis Emphasis, aka italics, with *asterisks* or _underscores_. Strong emphasis, aka bold, with **asterisks** or __underscores__. Combined emphasis with **asterisks and _underscores_**. Strikethrough uses two tildes. ~~Scratch this.~~ ## Lists 1. First ordered list item 2. Another item - Unordered sub-list. 1. Actual numbers don't matter, just that it's a number 1. Ordered sub-list 2. jiu9u 4. And another item. To have a line break without a paragraph, you will need to use two trailing spaces.⋅⋅ Note that this line is separate, but within the same paragraph.⋅⋅ (This is contrary to the typical GFM line break behaviour, where trailing spaces are not required.) * Unordered list can use asterisks - Or minuses + Or pluses ## Links [Kx navigation link](#/Testing) [I'm an inline-style link](https://www.google.com) [I'm an inline-style link with title](https://www.google.com "Google's Homepage") [I'm a reference-style link][Arbitrary case-insensitive reference text] [I'm a relative reference to a repository file](../blob/master/LICENSE) [You can use numbers for reference-style link definitions][1] Or leave it empty and use the [link text itself]. URLs and URLs in angle brackets will automatically get turned into links. http://www.example.com or and sometimes example.com (but not on Github, for example). Some text to show that the reference links can follow later. [arbitrary case-insensitive reference text]: https://www.mozilla.org [1]: http://slashdot.org [link text itself]: http://www.reddit.com ## Images Here's our logo (hover to see the title text): Inline-style: ![alt text](https://github.com/adam-p/markdown-here/raw/master/src/common/images/icon48.png "Logo Title Text 1") Reference-style: ![alt text][logo] [logo]: https://github.com/adam-p/markdown-here/raw/master/src/common/images/icon48.png "Logo Title Text 2" ## Code and Syntax Highlighting Inline `code` has `back-ticks around` it. ``` No language indicated, so no syntax highlighting. But let's throw in a tag. ``` ## Tables Table Header | ------------- | Content Cell | Content Cell | | Tables | Are | Cool | | ------------- |:-------------:| -----:| | col 3 is | right-aligned | $1600 | | col 2 is | centered | $12 | | zebra stripes | are neat | $1 | There must be at least 3 dashes separating each header cell. The outer pipes (|) are optional, and you don't need to make the raw Markdown line up prettily. You can also use inline Markdown. Markdown | Less | Pretty --- | --- | --- *Still* | `renders` | **nicely** 1 | 2 | 3 ## Block Quotes > Blockquotes are very handy in email to emulate reply text. > This line is part of the same quote. Quote break. > This is a very long line that will still be quoted properly when it wraps. Oh boy let's keep writing to make sure this is long enough to actually wrap for everyone. Oh, you can *put* **Markdown** into a blockquote. ## Horizontal Rules Three or more... --- Hyphens *** Asterisks ___ Underscores ## Line Breaks Here's a line for us to start with. This line is separated from the one above by two newlines, so it will be a *separate paragraph*. This line is also a separate paragraph, but... This line is only separated by a single newline, so it's a separate line in the *same paragraph*. ## YouTube [![A random YouTube video](https://img.youtube.com/vi/HfuZJVpNWR4/0.jpg)](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=HfuZJVpNWR4)

Resources:
FAQs:

>Q: Where can I find our Food Defense Response Plan?
A: *MCRP and ATO Plan*

>Q: What information should be included in the Food Defense Response?
A: *FPCON Security Measures, Plan of Action, Roles and Responsibilities, and Resources*

>Q: If intentional food contamination is suspected/evident who should I contact? 
A: *Law enforcement, ATO, USAFSAM/PHR, and...*

>Q: If a facility employee reports an unauthorized individual has had undetected access to the food supply, what does Public Health do?
A: *Place food on medical hold and secure it, contact USAFSAM/PHR and law enforcement*
